webTitle: Guardian Camera Club: Sabine Thoele's portfolio

fields.standfirst:
A review of Sabine Thoele's portfolio.

'German romanticism' is a beautifully constructed photo, with soft subtle tones making for a painterly image. The dynamic strength of 'Show me the way' is nicely done; 'Hanging in there' is simply magical. Looking like it was snapped from a train, 'Guesthouse' is oddly grim. 'Come to me' combines highlight and shade wonderfully, it's oddly funny too! The imagined narrative of 'What happened the day before' is intriguing, but the 'Vintage Fayre' poster rather spoils the mystery. Some of these images are wonderfully informed and observant
fields.headline: Guardian Camera Club: Sabine Thoele's portfolio
fields.trailText: A review of Sabine Thoele's portfolio

webTitle: Beautiful Games: football grounds from the streets

fields.standfirst: A combined passion for football and art has led Jamie Edwards on a mission to illustrate every football ground in the English leagues. From Boundary Park to Old Trafford, he captures the environments surrounding the hallowed stadiums, thereby locating football within a more precise and poignant geographical and social context. His observations are simple yet sharp, and often starkly industrial; they also remind us of the distant, anticipatory glimpse you get of a stadium's architecture and floodlights when approaching on a matchday. Edwards works with a sketchpad and camera, often from curious vantage points. He's drawn from hotels, bathrooms and a child's climbing frame
fields.headline: Beautiful Games: football grounds from the streets
fields.trailText: A combined passion for football and art has led Jamie Edwards on a mission to illustrate every ground in the English leagues

fields.standfirst: As George Osborne announces £11.5bn of cuts, our expert panel assesses the winners and losers
fields.byline: Polly Toynbee, Jonathan Portes, Melissa Kite, Sue Marsh, Tom Clark, Ian Mulheirn, Gavin Kelly and Tony Travers
fields.headline: Spending review 2013: panel verdict
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee, Jonathan Portes, Melissa Kite, Sue Marsh, Tom Clark, Ian Mulheirn, Gavin Kelly, Tony Travers: As George Osborne announces £11.5bn of cuts, our expert panel assesses the winners and losers

tags.bio: Jonathan Portes is director of the National Institute of Economic and Social Research and former chief economist at the Cabinet Office

Melissa Kite is contributing editor of The Spectator. She is the author of the book Real Life, published by Constable. She was deputy political editor of the Sunday Telegraph until 2011. Her alter ego is Tamzin Lightwater, who recounted life at Tory HQ in the anonymous Spectator satirical column, Diary of a Notting Hill Nobody

Sue Marsh is married with two small children. She campaigns to raise awareness of hidden disabilities and long term illness. A sufferer of severe Crohn's Disease for nearly three decades, Sue set up the blog Diary of a Benefit Scrounger to raise awareness of life with a chronic illness
Tom Clark is a leader writer for the Guardian.

Ian Mulheirn was appointed director of the Social Market Foundation in October 2008. He joined the Social Market Foundation as the chief economist in February 2008, after three years as an economic adviser at HM Treasury. He has worked in a variety of policy areas including child poverty, savings and investment, welfare to work and higher education funding. He leads the SMF's work on public service reform, and was recently a specialist adviser to the work and pensions committee inquiry into the Work Programme

Polly Toynbee is a columnist for the Guardian. She was formerly BBC social affairs editor, columnist and associate editor of the Independent, co-editor of the Washington Monthly and a reporter and feature writer for the Observer
Gavin Kelly is chief executive of Resolution Foundation, an independent thinktank aiming to improve living standards for low to middle income families in the United Kingdom
Tony Travers is director of the Greater London group at the London School of Economics

tags.bio: Alan Travis is the Guardian's home affairs editor. He is the author of Bound and Gagged, a history of British obscenity
Ian Black is the Guardian's Middle East editor. In more than 25 years on the paper he has also been its European editor, diplomatic editor, foreign leader writer and Middle East correspondent
Owen Bowcott is legal affairs correspondent. He was formerly the Guardian's Ireland correspondent and also worked on the foreign newsdesk
Mark Brown is the Guardian's arts correspondent. He has worked at the Guardian since 1996 in various jobs including the news desk and the arts desk

Owen Gibson is the Guardian's chief sports correspondent. From 2010 to 2012 he was Olympics editor, covering the build up to the London Games and writing on a range of other sporting issues. Prior to that, he was the Guardian's sports news correspondent and, before that, media correspondent for four years. He joined the Guardian in 2001 as new media editor and previously worked for trade title Media Week
Richard Adams is the Guardian's education editor. Follow him on Twitter: @RichardA

Richard Norton-Taylor regularly contributes to BBC news and current affairs programmes. He writes for The Guardian on defence and security and until recently was the paper's security editor. He won the Freedom of Information Campaign Award for journalism in 1986. He edits the Guardian Defence and Security blog with Nick Hopkins.

Email him at: richard.norton-taylor [at] guardian.co.uk
Phillip Inman is economics correspondent of the Guardian and Observer. He is the author of Managing Your Debt, a Which? essential guide
Gwyn Topham is the Guardian and Observer's transport correspondent. He has previously worked on the comment, news and travel sections.
Terry Macalister is energy editor of the Guardian. He has been employed at the paper and website for 12 years and previously worked for the Independent and other national titles

Mark Tran was appointed correspondent for the Guardian's Global development site in June 2011. He previously worked as a correspondent for the Guardian in Washington (1984-90) and New York (1990-99). Upon his return to London he covered business, domestic and international news for the website and the paper until his present position. Follow Mark on Twitter

Severin Carrell is Scotland correspondent for the Guardian. He has worked as a home affairs, environment and politics correspondent for the Scotsman and Scotland on Sunday, and as a senior reporter with the Independent and Independent on Sunday
Henry McDonald is the Observer's Belfast correspondent
Steven Morris is a reporter for the Guardian
Damian Carrington is the head of environment at the Guardian

Denis Campbell is health correspondent with the Guardian and the Observer. Since joining the Observer in 1999 he has covered sports news, social affairs and education. He previously worked for the Herald, Scotland on Sunday, Time Out and the Irish Times

Ian Sample has been a science correspondent for the Guardian since 2003. Before that, he was a journalist at New Scientist and worked at the Institute of Physics as a journal editor. He has a PhD in biomedical materials from Queen Mary's, University of London
